description: 14th century. From Middle English suasion, from Latin suāsiō (“counselling, advice, persuasion”), from Latin suādeō (“I urge, exhort; I suade, persuade”), from Proto-Italic *swādēō (“to recommend; to advise”), from Proto-Indo-European *swoh₂déye-, from *sweh₂d- (“sweet”).
Cognate with English suave (“charming, confident and elegant”), Italian suadere (“to persuade”) and Spanish suadir (“to persuade”).

entries.meaning: The act of urging or influencing; persuasion.
examples: The high intricate ways of the Keep had a strange power of suasion, an ability to carry conviction.
